title: Gordon Brown tells Scots: let us be a nation, united again - as it happened | Politics | The Guardian

text: scotland 's experiment of allowing more than 100,000 teens aged 16 to 17 to take part in this week 's independence referendum has demonstrated how the youngest voters can be some of the most enthusiastic in a mature democracy , the associated press reports .

shawn pogatchnik for ap writes that more than 90 % of the teenagers registered to vote and , to the surprise of many analysts , proved not so ready to rebel against their parents as might have been expected .
among the voters was sinead mcloughlin , 17 , who is quoted as saying : a lot of my friends say they voted just like the rest of their family .
there seemed to be more disagreement between the older ones , really .
i think more younger people did vote yes .
but we were n't quite the revolutionaries the snp thought we 'd be .
mcloughlin was among those who voted yes and was crestfallen at the result .
she added .
i 'm not too , too sad .
i 'm hoping the pandas will cheer me up !
i 'm going to wrap up the blog now .
thanks for reading .
the political differences opening up between the westminster parties since the referendum result have sparked some lively enough on debate on twitter .
the english singer billy bragg - who supported a yes vote - is among those who have come in , with bragg up on views expressed by the political commentator iain macwhirter .
billy bragg ( @ billybragg ) @ iainmacwhirter 2/2 please do n't turn inward and declare this is your fight alone .
we need the energy of the 45 to lead push for uk reform .
the observer and guardian photographer gary calton headed north to document the the independence referendum and a momentous week for scotland .
he covered official photocalls and news events , but also kept his eye open for instagram details that told the story and provided glimpses of what scotland looks like .
take a look at some of his work here .
i was with him when he took this one : gary calton ( @ garycaltonphoto ) robert the bruce statue aberdeen # indyref @ twitterid75
i neglected to include mention of today 's daily record earlier in the blog .
it splashes on the news alex salmond has signed off as scotland 's first minister , 'beaten but unbowed ' adding that he promised the people of scotland : the dream shall never die . '
also : jim waterson ( @ jimwaterson ) but today 's daily record for some great of a young alex salmond and a voucher for a free haggis .
we heard a little bit earlier about what the people behind all back to bowie 's are doing next .
it seems there 's also going to be news later today about the future of another artistic grouping formed before the referendum campaign .
national collective ( @ wearenational ) we 'll be making a statement about # indyref result and plans for the future at around 7pm .

documents.title: summary
text: promises made to scotland on further devolution will be upheld , gordon brown said , as he urged the country to come together after the bitter independence debate and find unity against the odds '' .

the former prime minister , who has spearheaded an accelerated timetable for the scottish parliament to get more powers , ruled out a political comeback but said he would ensure the commitment given by the leaders of the three main westminster parties is adhered to.. scotland 's decisive rejection of independence has sparked a frenetic constitutional bidding war between david cameron and ed miliband over the future shape of the uk .

as it became clear that 55 % of scottish voters had said no to independence , the prime minister demanded a new english settlement that would exclude scottish mps from voting on english matters , such as health and education .
labour leader ed miliband countered with a demand for a constitutional convention to review voting arrangements at westminster..
the better together campaign has released the full text of the motion being laid before the uk parliament by the three better together parties .

it was released in furtherance of the commitment to deliver more powers to the scottish parliament within an agreed timetable , '' according to a spokesperson for the campaign.. tributes have been paid to alex salmond after he announced he would be stepping down as leader of the snp and as scotland 's first minister .
his most likely successor , deputy first minister nicola sturgeon , has said meanwhile that there has been a surge in applications to join the snp in the past 36 hours .

documents.title: snp recruitment surge
text: they lost the referendum but they 're benefiting from an unprecedented recruitment surge since the result , according to scotland 's deputy first minister , nicola sturgeon .
she tweets : nicola sturgeon ( @ nicolasturgeon ) more than 4000 people have joined @ twitterid in last 36 hours .
many from labour , many new to politics .
be part of it - nicola sturgeon ( @ nicolasturgeon ) seems @ twitterid server is under pressure just now from people trying to sign up .
if you want to join , keep trying
around 1,000 people , including senior political figures from both sides of the referendum debate , are to attend a special church service in scotland where a message of unity will be delivered .

church of scotland moderator the rt rev john chalmers , who will lead the service tomorrow at st giles cathedral in the heart of edinburgh , will ask scots to put their differences aside and work together to redefine the country 's place within the uk .

he is expected to tell the gathering : the church here and in congregations across the country is playing its part in making it a little easier to stretch out that hand of friendship to those who are our fellow scots who did not support the side we supported .
how we voted on one particular day does not define who we are .

how we work together to put in place the democratic will of the scottish people will be defining - both for us as individuals and for us we as we work to redefine our place within the united kingdom .
those attending include shadow foreign secretary douglas alexander and scotland 's finance secretary john swinney .
as part of the event , those attending will light a single candle , symbolising a commitment to work together while swinney and alexander will each give a reading .
similar sentiments are expected to be aired at churches around scotland tomorrow after the moderator wrote to the kirk 's 800 ministers asking them to share similar thoughts .

in his letter , he said : we can not let ourselves be defined by which side we have been on , on 18 september ; instead we have to take the opportunity to define ourselves by our commitment to working together to build scotland 's future with shared purpose and shared values .

polling data of voters in the referendum has been released by the conservative peer lord ashcroft , who says it shows that the no campaign was right to focus on the currency and other uncertainties of independence .

he says 57 % of no voters said the pound was one of the most important factors in their decision , and the overarching reason for their decision was that the risks of becoming independent looked too great when it came to things like the currency , eu membership , the economy , jobs and prices . ''

this , ashcroft writes in a blog post , was a more powerful reason for most no voters ' decision than a strong attachment to the uk '' or the promise of the best of both worlds with guaranteed extra powers for the scottish parliament .
data from the ashcroft poll of more than 2,000 people who voted would appear to confirm expectations of the demographic breakdown to some extent .

the no campaign won among men , by a six-point margin , and by women , by 12 points , while older voters were the most decisively opposed to independence , with 73 % of those aged 65 or over voting no .
ashcroft adds : as the recent tightening in the polls suggested , those who made up their minds late in the campaign were more likely to choose independence .
two thirds of those who decided in the last few days voted yes ; no voters were much more likely than yes supporters to say they decided more than a year ago or always knew how they would vote .

the biggest single driver for yes voters was disaffection with westminster politics '' and the principle that all decisions about scotland should be taken in scotland '' was the most powerful overarching reason for a yes vote .
there 's also some interesting stuff on the silent no '' voters .
one in seven no voters told pollsters that they would be reluctant to tell their friends , family or colleagues how they had voted .
the full data tables can be downloaded here , or a summary from here if you prefer
remember that call by david bowie - delivered through the medium of kate moss at the brit awards - for scotland to stay with us '' ?
it inspired some folks alright , though not quite in the way that the singer intended .
pro-independence playwright david grieg brought together a range of scottish artists in a series of shows and podcasts exploring different referendum-related subjects from money to gender politics .
now the team behind 'all back to bowie 's ' have come up with a new project which they say is intended to bring the nation back together again , with simple acts of hospitality and discussion '' .
as part of it , they have released a postcard guide for scots holding your own 'all back to bowie 's ' discussion event .

members of the public are invited to find a venue ( ranging from their own front room to a town hall ) and propose a conversation that will discover 5 things for the country and 1 thing for each of us to do '' .

participants are asked to post their findings on the website whatsnowscotland.org or tweet to # whatnowscotland ' david bowie ( performing on another occasion ) made an unexpected intervention in the the debate over scottish independence at this year 's brit awards .
mok/pa

documents.title: catholic bishops commend salmond
text: scotland 's roman catholic bishops have commended alex salmond , expressing particular thanks for his support for catholic education in the country .

amid the reaction to salmond 's announcement on friday that he would be stepping down as snp leader and first minister , the bishops ' statement is notable given his long-term aim of making the party more attractive to scotland 's 850,000 catholics and perhaps even detoxify it in the eyes of some .
it 's a demographic that ceased to be labour 's most loyal voting group some time ago , while those from working class areas swung heavily to the snp in 2011 .

the letter , sent by the president of the bishops ' conference of scotland , archbishop philip tartaglia , says : with good reason , you have been described as one of the most able and influential political leaders that scotland and the united kingdom has ever produced .

it goes on to say : the bishops are especially grateful for your recognition of the important place of religion and faith in scotland , for your support of catholic education as making its own distinctive contribution to the good of scotland as a whole , and for your sensitivity to the issues around religious freedom which are emerging in our country as they are elsewhere .

speaking in manchester on the eve of his party 's conference , labour leader ed miliband indicated he was moving on from the alliance forged between the three main westminster parties in the scottish referendum campaign .
addressing activists , he said : the last few months have been about keeping our country together .
the next eight months are about how we change our country together .
and we know that yearning for change is there right across our country .
constitutional change matters , but we know that something else matters even more : this country does n't work for most working people and we , the labour party , are going to change it .

documents.title: better together parties ' parliamentary motion
text: the better together campaign has released the full text of the motion being laid before the uk parliament by the three better together parties : it is being released in furtherance of the commitment to deliver more powers to the scottish parliament within an agreed timetable , '' according to a spokesperson for the campaign .

here 's the text : that this house welcomes the result of the scottish independence referendum and the decision of the people of scotland to remain part of the united kingdom ; recognises that people across scotland voted‎ for a union based on the pooling and sharing of resources and for the‎ continuation of devolution inside the united kingdom ; notes the statement by the prime minister , deputy prime minister and leader of the opposition regarding the guarantee of and timetable for further devolution to scotland ; calls on the government to lay before parliament a command paper including the proposals of all three uk political parties by 30th october and to consult widely with the scottish people , civic scotland and the scottish parliament on these proposals ; further calls on the government to publish heads of agreement by the end of november and draft clauses for the new scotland bill by the end of january 2015 .

documents.title: snp : better together breaking promises
text: the scottish national party has accused the no campaign of failing to keep its promises '' on more powers for scotland .
a statement just issued by the snp says better together promised that : a day after the no vote , the timetable for further powers will be published as a motion before the uk parliament .
all uk parties will support this motion . ''
no motion has been published , says the party .
bruce crawford , an snp member of the scottish assembly , said : scots who chose to vote no on thursday were told they were voting for more devolution , so where is the missing motion ?
it does n't bode well for us that the no campaign - labour , the lib dems and the tories - have failed to keep their first promise .
the first part of the three westminster leader 's 'vow ' is already broken .
neither the 55 % who voted for it , or the 45 % who voted yes , will let this go .
the labour leader , ed miliband , has arrived in manchester for his party 's conference .
labour press team ( @ labourpress ) labour leader @ twitterid miliband arriving in manchester this morning # lab14
ending his speech , brown said that he had set out four ways in which people in scotland and the rest of the uk could unite for a common purpose .
we should consider serve scotland as an organisation that reflects our demand for social justice .
we should intensify the search for new jobs and skills by combining all our efforts to work together .
we should value the more positive relationships with england that the debate of the last few days outside scotland has made possible and that would reflect our increased self-confidence as a nation .

and we should consider how we can build what we pioneered - networks and relationships as part of a stronger civic society , free of partisan politics , where we are free to disagree but not to be disagreeable .

some more reaction to brown 's speech , including an interesting tweet from lord ashcroft , former deputy chairman of the conservative party : lord ashcroft ( @ lordashcroft ) gordon brown moving cameron 's feet towards the fire elsewhere , brown 's speech is being mulled over by many , who are considering what it means for his own legacy as much as what it means for the current debate about scotland and the rest of the uk .
nico hines ( @ nicohines ) so , gordon brown is re-writing britain 's entire political system before lunch on a saturday .
he 's a backbench mp .
mitch benn ( @ mitchbenn ) all this surprise at gordon brown 's `` resurrection '' ; he was n't `` the worst pm ever '' , he was just the unluckiest .
despite gordon brown 's speech , the elephant in the room is the political battle over how fast and how far to devolve political powers to england .

against the backdrop of pressure from tory mps and others , david cameron has demanded a new english settlement that would exclude scottish mps from ever voting on matters such as health and education in england .

there has been reaction to that today from the shadow communities and local government secretary , hilary benn , who stressed there could be no going back on the the timetable for scottish devolution set out by brown and agreed by the three westminster parties .

he criticised the prime minister 's announcement that the english reforms would be considered at the same time , telling bbc radio 4 's today programme : he conflated , on the one hand , a very solemn promise that all three parties made to the people of scotland about further devolution of power - and we must honour that promise to the timetable that was set out - with making decisions about how we are going to change the way in which our democracy works .
tory rory stewart , who represents penrith and the border , said : we have to make sure that england has some of the similar powers that have now been allocated to scotland .

lib dem peer lord tyler said : we should not start with english votes for english laws in the house of commons ; what we should start from is how do you get better democracy throughout the united kingdom ?
he 's talking about attitudes to privatisation and education in scotland and england , and says that the views of most people are broadly the same .
ninety percent of people want public services to be properly supported , he adds , while surveys have shown that most would be happy to pay more taxes to ensure this is the case .
another example of ( very intimate ) ties between england and scotland is the way in which dozens of scots every year benefit from organs donated by english people .
brown 's talking now about the reaction from other parts of the uk to the potential end of the union .
he cites the millions of tweets and discussion on social media , as well as rallies such as the gathering in trafalgar square in the run-up to the referendum .
some twitter reaction now while brown is still speaking euan mccolm ( @ euanmccolm ) man , brown is as good as it gets in the thumping political speech game .
robin brant ( @ robindbrant ) gordon doing his elder statesman routine : bill clinton rang me yesterday , spoke to kofi annan , frm pres of brazil 'great friend of mine ' .
kristy barker ( @ miss kristyb ) ca n't help feeling like brown 's going to be made the whipping boy when all these promises get reneged on .
liam clarke ( @ liamclarkecj ) what a speech from gordon brown in dalgety - passion , vision , the sweep of history .
could this be a comeback from the grave ?
# indyref
brown says that he wants to make another suggestion in relation to the feeling of powerlessness people have in the face of globalisation and the international flow of capital .

just as people in the 19th century took refuge and shelter in nationalist movements , he says that people today are looking for protection from societal and economic changes that they find bewildering '' .
less people are employed in scotland 's mining and manufacturing sector than in northern ireland , he says .
brown adds that there is no way forward other than cooperation between the scottish and uk government to deal with the changes that threaten jobs .
instead of a war of attrition '' between a uk and a scotland government , they should work together .
the war of words should end and be replaced by unified action , such as a commission or a task force to tackle issues such as joblessness .

he says that the yes and no posters and stickers should be cast aside - though given an honoured place in the history books '' : let us think of ourselves not as yes and no scots but simply as scots and let us be a nation , united again .
he also says that scotland 's flag should not be used as a weapon against opponents '' .
all the passion of the referendum campaign should be channelled and mobilised not just for a vote but for a better vision of society , brown adds .
he calls for more voluntary and social action in communities to create a more socially just scotland
brown tells the audience at dalgety bay primary school : i hope over these next few weeks that we will move from the acrimony to a form of amity .
he says that common ground can and should also be found beyond the move for constitutional change , mentioning some of the voters who had met during the week .
there are men and women in their 40s , 50s and 60s who had never even registered , let alone voted before .
he adds : we should be proud at that happened , particularly with so many young people being engaged .
the debate involving thousands of young people who questioned figures from both sides of the campaign was the best informed of all of the debates , he says .
he says that the devolved powers will ensure that no poll tax , no bedroom tax and no enforced rail privatisation will ever be enforced on scotland .
the powers will also ensure that the scottish parliament will have the ability to protect the national health service .
while it 's a programme for change that does not satisfy everybody 's ambitions , scotland will have the maximum devolution possible , in a way that will be supported by parties around the uk .
brown appeals to those on the yes side to look at these proposals objectively '' saying that the uk constitution can no longer be called unitary and centralised .
there is power sharing , resource sharing , wish sharing , '' he adds , citing the assemblies in northern ireland , wales and in london .
a resolution , which he and the three main westminster party leaders have signed , will be placed in the house of commons on monday it has set out a time table .
a command paper will be published in october and the draft legislation for a new scotland act will be ready by november .
the civil service is also already working on the proposals , he adds .
he has called a debate in the house of commons which will take place on the first week back on october 16 , when he says that he wants to ensure the timetable will become a certainty . ''
i am utterly convinced that whatever else happens the timetable and the powers that i set out two mondays ago when we talked about what would be devolved , will be delivered .
there is a time to fight and there is a time to unite , says brown , after quoting a biblical text which he says that his father might refer to .
he is sure that a way can be found to unify against the odds '' and wants to set out proposals that people can unite behind .
the first thing he wants to make clear is that the promises made last week by the three leaders of the uk 's main political parties must be and will be delivered .
the eyes of the world have been upon us and they will be on the three leaders : these are men that have been promise makers and they will not be promise breakers .
he wants to say today how the promises can be locked in .

documents.title: gordon brown speaking
text: gordon brown has taken the stage in fife now to deliver a speech in which he is expected to expand on his ideas for the future of the scotland .

he starts by thanking alex salmond for years of service as an mp and first minister , saying that although he has been a fierce and formidable opponent '' we owe him a debt of gratitude brown also thanks alistair darling for taking on a very different job as the leader of the better together campaign .

the 'glorious failure ' of the yes campaign in the referendum could yet be scotland 's finest hour , writes the author irvine welsh in today 's guardian .

the no voters should take a bow , according to the writer , as they provided the uk establishment with a reprieve that the enervated , confused and weak campaign of their masters certainly did n't deserve '' .

but he adds also that the yes campaign hit unexpected heights as the uk state was seen as 'failed ; antiquated , hierarchical , centralist , discriminatory , out of touch and acting against the people ' .
against this shabbiness the scots struck a blow for democracy , with an unprecedented 97 % voter registration for an election the establishment wearily declared nobody wanted .
it turns out that it was the only one people wanted .

whether this scottish assertiveness kickstarts an unlikely uk-wide reform ( unwanted in most of the english regions ) ; or wearies southerners and precipitates a reaction to get rid of them ; or the scots , through the ballot box at general elections , decide to go the whole hog of their own accord ; the old imperialist-based union is bust .

the scots , so often a regarded as a thrawn tribe with their best years behind them , have shown the western world that the corporate-led , neo-liberal model for the development of this planet , through g7 'sphere of influence ' states on bloated military budgets , has a limited appeal .
novelist irvine welsh says that the 'glorious failure ' of the yes campaign in the referendum could yet be scotland 's finest hour .
macleod
gordon brown is due to make today 's speech in his constituency of kirkcaldy and cowdenbeath in just over half an hour from now .

we know that he has already has crafted a detailed plan for a post-referendum constitutional settlement in the uk , including a new role for an elected house of lords as an arbiter in disputes between the four nations .
he 's also served notice that he intends to lead a major commons debate on the future of the union when the party conference season is over .

to some , brown is the man who saved the union , while no less a figure than peter mandelson , a political enemy after tony blair became labour leader in 1994 but who was recalled as a cabinet minister during brown 's stint as prime minister , is quoted in the independent : gordon brown saved david cameron 's bacon , and labour 's too .

in particular , the former chancellor 's defence of the union in a speech on wednesday was regarded by many as one the decisive moments of the campaign and was watched by 200,000 people on youtube within hours .

scotland 's decisive rejection of independence has sparked a frenetic constitutional bidding war between david cameron and ed miliband over the future shape of the united kingdom , reports the guardian 's patrick wintour today .

as it became clear that 55 % of scottish voters had said no to independence , the prime minister demanded a new english settlement that would exclude scottish mps from ever voting on english matters such as health and education .

miliband countered with a demand for a constitutional convention to review voting arrangements at westminster and the powers of english cities , and called for an elected second chamber to represent the regions and nations of the united kingdom .
if scottish mps were prevented from voting on english matters it would be far tougher for labour to secure a commons majority on a vast range of legislation .
david cameron responds on friday outside downing street to scotland 's referendum result .
pitarakis/ap
there has been some referendum fallout on the streets also .

at least six people were arrested amid angry scenes in glasgow last night as a group of young pro-union supporters clashed with pro-independence supporters who had been gathering in george square throughout the day .
police acted to separate a small group of pro-independence supporters from a group of skinheads believed to have marched from the loyalist pub the louden tavern in nearby duke street .
the guardian 's libby brooks was there and reports that individuals argued over the referendum result and a chorus of rule britannia was countered by flower of scotland .

sam tonks , an engineer from uddingston , told her that he had driven into the city with his wife and daughter because he wanted to celebrate the referendum victory with other no supporters , but had been greeted by something much uglier .
it 's on both sides.the city is divided by religion already and to be honest i think the union jacks and saltires are a bit of an excuse .
glasgow police keep opposing elements apart in george square on friday night .

here are some of the political events and issues on the horizon today in the aftermath of the referendum : .

former labour leader gordon brown , whose intervention in the campaign has been credited with helping to secure a no vote , will spell out the next steps he wants to see in scotland , and how to heal the wounds caused by a bruising referendum campaign.. labour activists are gearing up for the party 's annual gathering today with the constitutional fallout from the scottish referendum battle set to loom large..
the scottish national party has a vacancy for a leader for the first time in a decade .

speaking minutes after salmond 's announcement , deputy first minister nicola sturgeon said yesterday that she could think of no greater privilege '' than to succeed salmond as snp leader and first minister , but that the decision is not for today '' .

good morning and welcome to live blog coverage of reaction and fallout to scotland 's referendum , in which 55 % of scottish voters said no to independence - a higher margin than suggested by the final opinion polls of the campaign .

as political leaders now grappling with the referendum result , former prime minister gordon brown will today set out his ideas for the future of scotland while political wrangling in westminster continues over downing street 's plans for sweeping constitutional reform across the united kingdom .
achieved only after last ditch concessions by the uk political parties , the final tally of votes saw the no campaign won 55.3 % , compared to 44.7 % for yes .
the result has also sparked the planned resignation of alex salmond , who has dominated scottish politics for the past decade , and who has said he would quit in november .

despite the defeat , that figure was a high water mark for the independence movement and the scottish national party and a months-long constitutional battle now seems certain , writes my colleague severin carrell .
